job_title: Administrative Assistant II in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco has few perks and pros nowadays
cons:
I began as a temp in the 90s for Cisco. They were a high-end employer with a keen eye for keeping employees comfortable and motivated. But in the last decade my stints with them had become disappointing. The Executive Assistants in any given unit will make or break you depending on if you are sufficiently obedient -- expressing confidence and expertise puts you in the dog house. The upper-level management is over 80% Indians with 60% of workers on SOWs from India and China; and the CEO pushes the woke agenda to the point you're rotated out if you aren't on board. Managers turn a blind eye to the internal politics. There are a lot of good people here, like any company. But contractors are looked down on by the administrative staff; and there's so many limits on permissions that you can barely get your job done. 

As an experienced EA with decades of proven expertise, I expected my stint w/the flag-ship team to end in being recommended for other opportunities. But instead, I quickly realized the existing EAs were not only uninterested in someone coming in with organizational skills and top-level support but they resented it. One even said to me, 'Well, you're gonna make me look bad.' This is the same person who admonished me for following the direction of a senior director and ultimately feigned some problem with me in order to take the heat off themselves. She already had numerous complaints against her but they were ignored.  I was glad to leave there when my contract ended.  

While they once prided themselves on a great work environment, the office space now is uncomfortable, stiff, and not user-friendly.  They were closing down buildings at a massive rate, and revamping current buildings to reflect the sparse, lower-functioning, remote work style even before the pandemic. Most of the new techies quit within 2 years and go elsewhere, and probably an even higher percent if they are American. It's just too hard to compete with the foreign pool of lower-paid workers. They seem to have adopted a business model of harvesting top-tier graduates, squeezing them dry and forcing them out to bring in the next level of top-tier, entry pay-grade talent. 

Instead of being a respectable, responsible business model for the industry, they've become a machine where the goal is to make it look good on the drawing board but everything else suffers. 

I wouldn't go back, especially not for the below-standard pay they offer the administrative staff.

pros: Cisco Systems hires brightest talents in the market. Well-educated, open minded, experienced, sociable, eager to face new challenges, constantly pushing themselves out of the comfort zone and working on continuous improvement. Great management and very supportive. I did not feel hierarchy pressure and could address my concern or question to the top of the top of senior leadership. Senior leadership always backs salesforce out there in the field, generating demand and making revenue for the company. Cisco Systems also emphasizes internal mentorship and coaching programs, pushes team for trainings and continuous learning. Great company to work for.
cons: Supply chain, logistics, slow internal processing clock speed leads to issues with customer experience and satisfaction. Sometimes, it is easier to cancel the initial order placement and request a new shipment, which has high chances to arrive early. Sometimes it is hard to engage security team to make a demo or pilot for a customer whose business is small or medium, perhaps this has improved in the last three years.

job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: great coworkers, leadership team tries, good benefits
cons: Layoffs ,“LR”s multiple times a year.. this really delays projects when you’re regularly losing a stakeholder or team member to LRs. During the beginning of the pandemic I was told repeatedly there was no guarantee my role was secure. The ceo claims he wont lay people off during the pandemic.. then 2 months later say theres going to be a massive layoff of 10-12% of the company in October. The additional stress and attempt to normalize the fear of losing your job constantly.. NO THANK YOU. Also huge RTP presence means lots of conservative, christian republicans. Lots of work needed in the D&I space. No formal review, no chance of promotion. People are treated as replaceable resources. 3 managers in 2 years. Didnt see a single team mate promoted in 3 years, even people that had been there 6+ years. Employees have Stockholm syndrome, “feel so lucky they survived the last LR”. The pay is horrrrible for the bay area and they do not give annual increases.. period. If youre lucky youll get a promotion every 5 years. If you are able to keep the same manager for more than 8 months. How this place makes it to the “best places to work” list..... they're clearly bribing someone.

job_title: Technical Solutions Architect in Lake Oswego, OR
pros:
Cisco pays well, bonuses for performance, unless you really knock it out of the park, and makes an effort to manage its employees effectively.

Cisco is confronting a new and rapidly evolving business as they try to transform to a software driven business. Employees with those skills are going to find Cisco a great short term opportunity. Then the politics step in.
cons:
Most of your managers will turn over in a year or two. It takes longer for the least competent to be replaced however.

The world is becoming software. Cisco is hugely dependent on Software, but their business models emphasize hardware. Consequently, their ability to execute to the rapid pace in the software world is challenged. This hurts your ability to fully maximize sales programs and leaves technical people in a support quagmire. 

Cisco is not a place for the long term. During my tenure my entire office of "Gray Lizards", people with decades of experience, customer relationships and technical knowledge of the quirks of older systems and how to keep them going, was riffed and we got a 42 page memo showing that in addition to those of us over 50, they had also removed several people who were 30 and thus no ageism existed in their decisions. While hard to accept, I do appreciate that times are changing for Cisco and they need to change with them.

Mid-Level "Faces" of the company change annually - indicating that priorities and investments are changing as well. Does not bode well for longer term employment stability after 2-3 years, especially if you are a project manager.

As with any company, politics is rife the higher you go. But at Cisco, the impact of politics is felt at operational levels in terms of investments, timelines rewards, and constraints. Duplicity is very common around projects that once held great promise, but now have new people with new priorities in place.

review_title: A great company to work, but a lot of scope to improve.
pros:
I think we need to evaluate a company based on many fronts.

1. Continuous learning: Cisco invests a lot in employees' learning. There are a lot of training offerings (paid-free, instructor-led - virtual), which anyone can enroll and learn a new skill. We can apply these new skills in any POC project and showcase them in wider forums, and get them productized.

2. Multiple companies: Cisco can be treated as multiple companies under one roof. Employees have the option of testing different waters and settle in their choice. We plan our own future.

3. Tons of great ancillary options: Be it Gym, medical support, reasonable WFH, no-strict 9-5 regime, healthy food menu in the canteen, Cisco has it all.
cons:
Turning to the other side of the coin, Cisco has its own share of improvements to focus on. To start with:

1. Agility: Cisco is heavily banking on the brand and vast customer base. It has to move out of its comfort zone and play a vital role in the 'Innovation' area and be agile.

2. Pay: End of the day, paycheck matters too, nothing can compensate for that. It's widely known that Cisco is not a great paymaster. Time and again it was brought to management notice, but negligible improvements so far. The HR team has to innovate themselves on how to retain people, improve employee happiness index, and shed the legacy model of hikes and promotions.

review_title: Social conscious but stuck in the 90s and overly disorganized
pros:
- They genuinely care about DEI initiatives 
- My team and leads were professional/helpful
cons:
- There is literally no organization and no one knows where to get information. I've never worked somewhere that had such a weird stronghold on information. You would get sent in 15 directions to complete a tasks, getting different answers from 15 people along the way. Efficiency falls by the way side of "we've always done it this way" or "that's just the way it is". 

- Countless meetings that had nothing to do with my role or anything remotely helpful. Everyone outside my immediate team seemed like the "fake nice" persona, pretending to care but you could see through it. There's no structure of these pieces are important, focus on this. Also, the amount of "trainings" people are forced to do are a time suck. 

- Everyone knows the pay scales are much lower than competitors and they don't seem to really care. If you interview there, 9/10 times you're going to get low balled on salary. Don't even get me started about the aggressively low pay they attempt to throw at Canadian employees. They act like they want to change it but nothing moves in an agile manner at Cisco so if you want fair pay, look elsewhere.

review_title: Worst place to start your career
pros: None except a chill life with no learning or pressure and some peanuts salary
cons:
Okay hear me out whoever is reading this - 
These are some of the points:
 -  Cisco is a crumbling place. In next 15-20 years it no longer will stay in business because it is becoming less and less relevant.It is surrounded by many competitors everywhere who are increasing their market share. Don't fall for the HR or CEO saying it's a best place to work.
- If you get into Cisco make sure you ask which team it is for and go on LinkedIn find people who are working and ask them for their review. There are many teams who have useless work and pathetic culture especially in India.
- I worked at a team called identity services engine. So heads up it's not a good team to be in especially for any fresher. Do not make the same mistake as I did by joining this place. Same goes to some other teams as well.
- If you are a new grad I request you to not join Cisco as there are no smart people left. Most of them have already left because of poor pay and bad culture. It's way better to work in some startup than here. So I request you to not ruin your career coming to this place.
- The management is as worse as it can get. Internal politics, lack of care for employer voice, etc.. the list is endless. 
- Even if you join by mistake just learn about things not to do in Cisco and move out of this place fast

review_title: It's all about the management team
job_title: Senior Business Architect in Raleigh, NC
pros: Cisco is a forward-looking company, but execution does sometimes get wrapped around the axle of politics. Cisco manages to stay where it is through the occasional big technology breakthrough, like Encrypted Traffic Analytics and thanks to brand, heft, and the fact that no one ever got fired for buying Cisco. The company is making good progress now in their transformation from a products company to a software/subscriptions company. This is an amazing accomplishment that should be credited to Chuck Robbins and his management team. While John Chambers grew a behemoth from a strong up-and-comer, and was a wizard at integration of acquisitions (for the most part), but he could not make this transformation, though he'd tried for years. It's a company with a bright future in cloud and security.
cons: Too many decisions are made because of the HiPPO (Highest Paid Person's Opinion), whether or not it's the right thing to do. Look at key competitors from Zoom to Juniper to see talented folks who took their good ideas elsewhere and peeled off market share.

cons: The area the company needs to focus on is laying off the employees who are not performing or are on performance improvement plans.  I saw a lot of very talented and intelligent employees with proven track records get impacted by the layoffs and noticed the under performing employees are still there.  They also need to spend some time focusing on the international employees as well.  I worked with a lot of international folks who were not performing but managed to not be impacted by the layoffs due to country laws.  The company really needs to take a closer look at that as well.

review_title: CSAP kickstarted my career off in the best possible way!
pros: I was lucky enough to start off my career during the pandemic because Cisco made it possible. They also went above and beyond to make sure their employees were taken care of during these times. It is a cliché, but the best part about Cisco is all the great people you will meet and work with. Even though I am working from home, I am still motivated every day to get out of bed and see my colleagues over Webex and help our customer and partners to succeed in the best possible way.
cons: Cisco is one of the biggest IT companies in the world and is therefore divided into several smaller "sections" that make up the company as a whole. That makes me feel like one in a million (or 1:75,000), so if you want to stand out and make a name for yourself it is probably harder to do that in Cisco than in other smaller companies.

review_title: The BPTW awards are not just for the show.
job_title: Technical Solutions Specialist in Feltham, England
pros:
Let me start by saying that the company is huge and the company structure can be complicated while also consisting of countless teams. Every team might have different objectives, approaches, and the way they do their business. However, my review is based on my current team - Global Virtual Engineering (GVE).

Due to the size of the companies, there can be quite a few changes happening every quarter and that is why I already had three different managers situated in three different countries. However, every single one of them shared the same principle - trust. 

They trust you to use your instinct to manage your workload as well as choose the projects to work on. They then also provide you with all the support that you need - no micro-management! As long as you get the job done at the end of the quarter, then no one feels like they need to monitor your every step and make sure that you actually sit in front of your screen from 9-6 pm.

You are given complete freedom to manage your workload and focus on projects that are relevant to your experience as well as any other areas of interest.

The benefits are truly world-class too - everything ranging from the pension plan, life insurance, health insurance, and dental insurance is brilliant. I am not talking about the bare minimum where 99% of cases are not covered anyway.

The compensation is also great compared to what I have seen in the industry. The bonus plans are clearly defined and you know exactly what is expected of you to reach the goal - no gray areas.

I also feel like if something urgent happens and you cannot work for some reason, the company will support you. No need to book a full day of PTO one month in advance for a 1 hour GP/Dentist visit, either.

The training and development opportunities are also countless. I am not necessarily talking about Cisco certifications. The company understands that in order to be successful, we also need to learn about other products or platforms, and they provide all the support we need.

While the objectives I need to hit in order to progress in my career are not as clearly defined, I can see that good efforts are always appreciated in a fair way throughout the fiscal year.

There are numerous ways to get engaged with different teams or with your managers and directors. They are generally accessible so all you have to do is reach out!

I guess my biggest advice when interviewing for any of the roles is to be passionate about the topic and be honest.

My biggest advice to you once you start working here is to get your name out there whenever possible, use common sense and do not take advantage of the trust given to you by your team and managers.
cons: Sometimes, it can feel way too formal and corporate, so you do not really discuss things with other employees on a more personal level.

pros: Great culture, promoting work/life balance and flexibility; great benefits; great talent and people; the good managers I had were excellent
cons: The company restructures every 6-12 months, so job security can be limited. I transitioned into a new role in a time when things were settling from a restructure, in a team with a new, very politically motivated leader, and the people involved in my hiring jumped ship and found new roles internally and externally. I really felt like the company let me down, as I kind of got lost in the shuffle, despite my efforts to speak up. If I had stayed in my original role, or if the timing had been better, I think I'd likely still be employed there. BUT they do provide excellent support to those whose jobs are cut, through a strong severance and support services for looking both internally and externally to find a new job.

pros: Accumulated stock awards are attractive if you are at the Principal Engineer/Director level
cons:
Two years on from my departure and I still struggle to identify anything remotely positive about Cisco beyond staying for share options. Continual, stealth headcount reductions after each quarter's results have gradually removed those with the energy and creativity that Cisco desperately needs to reinvent itself. For those early-in-career, I'm not convinced that having Cisco on the resume/CV helps. My experience is it can hinder you when applying to new roles as you are tarred with having worked in a slow-moving, behemoth company rather than a fast-moving agile start-up.

Let's face it - this is a company that should have owned the whole videoconference market in the wake of COVID-19 via WebEx yet it is Zoom that has stolen both the zeitgeist and the market. That should be enough for the Board to call for Chuck to step down and for them to bring in a visionary technology leader rather than yet another senior salesperson with a strategy that only looks 2 quarters out in a vain attempt to keep Wall St happy...
